title: Hart v. SCDOT
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jeffery R. Hart, Respondent,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Transportation, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Diane S. Goodstein, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-432
Heard May 7, 2008 â€“ Filed August 4, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Andrew F. Lindemann, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				David Whittington, of Summerville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  In this personal injury
  action, the South Carolina Department of Transportation appeals a verdict for Plaintiff
  Jeffery R. Hart.Â  The questions presented in this appeal are: Â (1) whether the
  Department was entitled to claim sovereign immunity under the South Carolina
  Tort Claims Act; and (2) whether the trial judge erred in directing a verdict
  on the Departmentâ€™s defense of comparative negligence.Â  We affirm.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL
  HISTORY
Hart was employed as
  a senior patrol officer by the Town of Holly Hill.Â  On December 1, 2002, Hart
  began his patrol shift around 9:00 p.m., expecting to work until seven oâ€™clock
  the following morning.Â  During the early morning hours of his shift, Hart
  observed a vehicle stop at two residences one block apart from each other.Â  At
  both stops, the driver of the car hastily exited the vehicle and quickly
  approached the house.Â  When he observed the vehicle make a left turn without a
  turn signal, Hart instructed another officer on duty in the vicinity to
  initiate a traffic stop.Â  In addition, because of the behavior of the driver,
  Hart wanted â€œto make sure everything was still going to be okay with the person.â€
The officer whom Hart had instructed to initiate the
  traffic stop informed Hart by radio that the vehicle did not pull over after
  activation of the blue light.Â  When Hart heard the siren in the background, he
  activated the blue light and siren on his own vehicle and joined in the
  pursuit.
During the pursuit,
  Hart observed the vehicles of both the suspect and the accompanying officer
  stop at two stop signs.Â  Furthermore, neither vehicle ran any stop signs.Â  After
  the suspect feigned a stop, the vehicle Hart was driving became the primary car
  behind the suspectâ€™s vehicle.
Because
  Hart had never been on the road on which the suspect was leading him, he asked
  the Orangeburg County dispatch if there was a deputy in the area.Â  At no time
  did either Hartâ€™s vehicle or the suspectâ€™s vehicle ever exceed eighty miles per
  hour.[1]Â 
  Throughout the pursuit, Hart maintained a following distance of about six to
  eight car lengths.
The paved, straight road on which the two vehicles
  were proceeding dead-ended into a dirt road; however, there was no stop sign at
  the intersection.Â  The suspect did not stop at the intersection, which caused
  her vehicle to go airborne into the woods, resulting in fatal injuries.Â 
  Similarly, Hart was unable to stop or take other evasive action and sustained
  bodily injuries when his vehicle crashed into the same wooded area. Â Hart
  estimated both vehicles were traveling at a speed of seventy-two miles per hour
  when they reached the intersection.
On November 10,
  2004, Hart commenced this action under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act
  against the Department, alleging the Department was negligent in failing to
  have appropriate signage at the intersection. Â In its answer, dated January 19,
  2005, the Department denied the allegations in the complaint and made the
  following assertions as affirmative defenses: Â (1) the acts or omissions of
  third parties not within its control superseded and intervened to such an
  extent as to negate any effect of its own negligence; (2) punitive damages were
  not recoverable; (3) the acts or omissions allegedly constituting negligence
  were not actionable because they resulted from the exercise of discretion or
  judgment; (4) Hartâ€™s own negligence barred any recovery; and (5) the Department
  was entitled to â€œany defense under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-10 et seq. not already pled above.â€
A jury trial in the
  matter took place on January 9, 2006.Â  At the close of Hartâ€™s case and again at
  the close of its own case, the Department moved for a directed verdict on the
  following three grounds:Â  (1) Hart failed to prove the Department had actual or
  constructive notice of the missing stop sign; (2) Hartâ€™s negligence was greater
  than 50 percent and he should not recover under comparative negligence law; and
  (3) Hartâ€™s sole remedy was through the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Act.Â  The trial judge rejected all three grounds and denied the motion.
Hart also moved for directed verdicts on the issue of
  liability and on the Departmentâ€™s comparative negligence defense.Â  Although the
  trial judge submitted the issue of liability to the jury, she directed a
  verdict for Hart on the issue of comparative negligence, thus striking that
  defense.
The
  jury returned a verdict in Hartâ€™s favor in the amount of $1,000,000.Â  The
  Department then filed post-trial motions for judgment notwithstanding the
  verdict (JNOV), for a new trial absolute, and to alter or amend the judgment.Â  By
  order dated April 6, 2006, the trial judge granted the Departmentâ€™s motion to
  alter or amend the judgment, reducing the verdict to $300,000 in accordance
  with the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, but denied the Departmentâ€™s other
  motions.Â  Specifically, the trial judge found the Department had constructive
  notice â€œbecause [it] was under a continuing duty to check the intersection
  bi-monthly or six (6) times a year, plus a night inspection annually.â€Â  The
  trial judge also found there was no evidence that Hart was negligent under the
  circumstances of the case.Â  Finally, the trial judge rejected the Departmentâ€™s
  claim that the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act was Hartâ€™s only remedy.
  Â This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The trial court is required to view the evidence and reasonably
  drawn inferences in the light most favorable to the non-moving party when
  ruling on motions for directed verdict and JNOV.Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 345, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003).Â  The court should deny the
  motion when the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in
  doubt.Â  Id.Â  â€œThe appellate court
  will reverse the trial courtâ€™s ruling on a JNOV motion only when there is no
  evidence to support the ruling or where the ruling is
  controlled by an error of law.â€Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C.
  424, 434-435, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006) (citing Hinkle v. Natâ€™l Cas. Ins. Co., 354 S.C. 92, 96, 579 S.E.2d 616, 618 (2003)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  The
  Department asserts the trial judge should have ruled it was entitled to protection
  from liability under section 15-78-60(14) of the South Carolina Tort Claims
  Act.Â  We find no reversible error.
In her
  post-trial order, the trial judge gave three reasons for rejecting the
  Departmentâ€™s argument that Hartâ€™s sole remedy for his injuries was through the
  South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act:Â  (1) the issue had not been properly
  raised to the court; (2) South Carolina Code section 15-78-60(14) did not bar
  Hart from pursuing a personal injury claim against the Department because he
  â€œwas employed by the Town of Holly Hill, not by the State or the South Carolina
  Department of Transportationâ€; and (3) even if section 15-78-60(14) were
  applicable, Hart could still recover against the Department under the dual
  persona doctrine because he was suing the Department for breach of duties that
  were wholly independent of any owed to him as an employee of the Town of Holly
  Hill.Â  A decision by this Court to uphold any one of these three grounds is
  sufficient to affirm the trial judgeâ€™s determination that Hart was not limited
  to recovery under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act for his injuries.Â  See Weeks v. McMillan, 291 S.C. 287, 292, 353 S.E.2d 289, 292
  (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œWhere a decision is based on alternative grounds, either of
  which independent of the other is sufficient to support it, the decision will
  not be reversed even if one of the grounds is erroneous.â€).
We
  agree with the trial judge that the issue of whether the Department was immune
  from liability under section 15-78-60(14) was not properly presented to the
  trial court.
Under
  the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, â€œ[t]he State, an agency, a
  political subdivision, and a governmental entity are liable for their torts in
  the same manner and to the same extent as a private individual under like
  circumstancesâ€ subject to limitations and exemptions from liability and damages
  as provided within the Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-40 (2005).Â  One such
  exception to the waiver of immunity is contained within section 15-78-60(14).Â 
  That section provides in pertinent part that â€œ[t]he governmental entity is not
  liable for a loss resulting from . . . any claim covered by the South Carolina
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, except claims by or on behalf of an injured employee
  to recover damages from any person other than the employer . . . .â€Â  Id. Â§ 15-78-60(14).Â  As with other limitations on liability under the Act, however,
  the burden of establishing this exception is on the governmental entity
  asserting it as an affirmative defense.Â  Clark v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Pub.
    Safety, 362 S.C. 377, 386, 608 S.E.2d 573, 578 (2005).Â  Moreover, as an
  affirmative defense, this exception â€œmust be specifically pled to be considered.â€Â 
  61A Am. Jur. 2d Pleading Â§ 295 (1999).Â  See also 71 C.J.S. Pleading Â§ 198 (2000) (â€œA plea or answer setting up new matter as a defense generally
  must contain a statement of facts and should be certain and precise.â€).
Even if we were to
  accept the Departmentâ€™s argument in its reply brief that the question of
  whether Hartâ€™s accident was covered under the South Carolina Workersâ€™
  Compensation Act was a matter of law, we share the trial judgeâ€™s concern
  regarding how the Department attempted to raise this issue.Â  In its answer, the
  Department made only a nonspecific reference to â€œany defense under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act
  . . . not already pled above.â€Â  At no time during this litigation did the Department expressly assert section 15-78-60(14) as an
  affirmative defense or as a ground for summary judgment.Â  Moreover,
  although Rule 15(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure allows
  pleadings to be amended as necessary to conform to the evidence, here there was
  nothing in the record before us on which to base an amendment of the
  Departmentâ€™s answer to include the specific affirmative defense that it was
  entitled to immunity because Hartâ€™s claim should have been covered by workersâ€™
  compensation.[2]
Under
  these circumstances, we do not fault the trial judge for her reservations about
  deciding this issue.Â  Absent from the record is any indication before its
  directed verdict motion that the Department ever intended to rely on section
  15-78-60(14) as an affirmative defense.Â  Cf. Turner v. Cent. Local
    Sch. Dist., 706 N.E.2d 1261, 1264 (Ohio 1999) (reversing the grant of the
  defendant school districtâ€™s motion to include a statutory immunity defense in
  part because the district failed to assert the defense in a timely manner and
  its failure to do so made it reasonable for the plaintiffs to assume the
  defense would be waived).
2.Â  The Department also
  contends the trial judge erred in directing a verdict on its defense that Hart
  was negligent, thus preventing the jury from apportioning fault on the basis of
  Hartâ€™s alleged comparative negligence.Â  We disagree.
Under South
  Carolina Code section 56-5-760, the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle
  may â€œexceed the maximum speed limit if he does not endanger life or propertyâ€
  when appropriate audible and visual signals on the vehicle are activated.Â  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-760(B)(3) (2006).Â  This section further provides that its
  protections â€œdo not relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from
  the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons.â€Â  Id. Â§ 56-5-760(D).Â  
On appeal, the
  Department contends Hart failed to exercise due care for his own safety by (1)
  pursuing a traffic offender at an excessive rate of speed in the dark and in an
  area with which he was unfamiliar; (2) following the lead vehicle too closely
  and failing to maintain a proper lookout; and (3) failing to terminate the
  search according to the Holly Hill Police Policy and Procedure for police
  pursuits.Â  We agree with the trial judge that none of these grounds gave rise
  to an inference Hart was negligent.
We acknowledge that
  the pursuit took place at night and that Hart admitted he had exceeded the
  posted speed limit and did not know the area.Â  Nevertheless, it was also
  undisputed that the weather conditions were good and the road on which both
  vehicles were traveling was straight and paved.Â  Moreover, there was no evidence
  that the same accident would not have occurred even if Hart was traveling the
  speed limit.Â  See Horton v. Greyhound, 241 S.C. 430, 439, 128
  S.E.2d 776, 781 (1962) (â€œThe concurrence of excessive
  speed with this primary, efficient cause of the collision does not impose
  liability on the defendants unless, without it, the collision would not have
  occurred.â€).
As to
  the Departmentâ€™s allegations that Hart followed the suspect vehicle too
  closely, the only pertinent evidence is Hartâ€™s testimony that he maintained a
  following distance of approximately six to eight car lengths consistent with
  his training.Â  Furthermore, the only evidence regarding whether Hart kept a
  proper lookout was his testimony on cross-examination that, contrary to what
  the Department was trying to establish, his attention was not focused exclusively
  on the suspect vehicle.Â  There is no evidence that either Hart or the suspect
  had driven erratically.Â  As noted earlier in this opinion, both vehicles had
  stopped at stop signs twice during the pursuit.
Finally, we
  reject the Departmentâ€™s assertion that Hart should have ended the pursuit.Â  Regardless
  of whether written procedures warranted termination of the pursuit, the trial
  judge found â€œ[t]here was no evidence otherwise presented that [Hart] should
  have abandoned his pursuit due to the endangerment of life or property.â€ Â Although,
  as the Department noted in its brief, Hart admitted he would have terminated
  the pursuit for safety reasons if it had continued on the dirt road
  intersecting the road on which both vehicles were traveling just before the
  accident, the pursuit ended while both vehicles were still on the paved road
  and crashed into the woods. Â We have found no evidence in the recordâ€”and the
  Department has not directed our attention to anyâ€”of hazards appearing before
  the accident that should have prompted Hart to discontinue the pursuit.
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS,
  THOMAS, and PIEPER, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  The posted speed limit on the road was fifty-five
  miles per hour.
[2]Â  The trial judge observed the record was â€œcompletely
  void as to any evidence of [Hartâ€™s] entitlement to benefits under the South
  Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act,â€ and, when arguing his directed verdict
  motion, counsel for the Department conceded â€œthereâ€™s no evidence in the record
  in the workersâ€™ compensation claim.â€

title: Edwards v. Edwards
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Douglas Jay
      Edwards, Respondent/Appellant
				v.
				Frances L.
      Edwards, Appellant/Respondent
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Aphrodite K. Konduros, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-433
Submitted March 1, 2008 â€“ Filed August 4,
  2008
AFFIRMED IN PART AND HELD IN ABEYANCE IN PART


	
		
			
				William N. Epps, Jr., of Anderson, for Appellant-Respondent.
				Robert M. Rosenfeld, of Greenville, for Respondent-Appellant.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this domestic action, Frances Edwards (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s order
  reducing alimony payments of Douglas
  Edwards (Husband).Â  Husband cross-appeals arguing the family
  court erred in finding him in contempt, imposing a contempt sanction, awarding
  Wife attorneyâ€™s fees, and allowing evidence of previous testimony.Â  Husband
  also contends a state court lacks jurisdiction, outside the realm of alimony, to interfere with repayment
  of his debts pursuant to Chapter 13 bankruptcy.Â  We affirm the reduction in
  alimony and hold the remaining issues in abeyance due to Husbandâ€™s bankruptcy
  action.[1] 
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married in 1966.Â  In 2000, Wife filed for
  divorce.Â  The family court granted Wife a divorce on the ground of adultery and
  awarded Wife $1,673 per month in regular periodic alimony.Â  Prior to the
  divorce hearing, Husband and Wife had reached a settlement agreement involving
  the equitable division of their real and personal property through two letters
  between counsel.Â  The family court approved
  this settlement agreement and merged and incorporated these letters by reference into the
  divorce order.Â  This agreement involved
  the equitable division of a family business, Central Catering and CafÃ© (the
  CafÃ©), and a business vehicle
  owned by the CafÃ©.Â  
After their divorce, Husband accepted a severance package and
  retired from his job with Michelin in 2002.Â  Thereafter, he began
  focusing entirely on the CafÃ© and wished to expand the business.Â  However,
  after losing a longtime lease, Husband began losing money in the CafÃ©.Â 
  Additionally, Arvidiaâ€™s Deli, an expansion restaurant Husband opened, failed a
  year after its opening.Â  Based on these events, Husband petitioned the family
  court for a reduction in his alimony obligation.Â  Wife counterclaimed, arguing
  Husbandâ€™s changed circumstances did not warrant a reduction in his alimony
  obligation and sought immediate payment of all equitably divided marital
  property.Â  Additionally, Wife alleged Husband was in willful contempt of court
  for his failure to pay Wife her portion of their marital estate pursuant to the
  original divorce decree.Â  
On June 6, 2005, the family court issued an order reducing
  Husbandâ€™s monthly alimony obligation from $1,673 to $400 based on his changed
  circumstances.Â  The family court also found Husband in contempt for failing to
  pay Wife her share of the marital property, Cobra benefits, and attorneyâ€™s fees
  and costs pursuant to the original divorce decree.Â  The family court ordered
  Husband to pay Wife $34,411.77 within 30 days, and if he failed to pay, to
  serve 90 days in the Greenville County Detention Center.Â  Additionally, the
  family court ordered Husband to pay Wife $7,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees which Wife
  incurred during the contempt case.Â  
Husband unsuccessfully sought a stay of the contempt order from
  the family court and this court.Â  He subsequently filed Chapter 13 bankruptcy.Â 
  The federal bankruptcy court established a payment schedule under which Husband
  would pay back his creditors, including paying debts he owed to Wife.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On
  appeal from a family court order, the appellate court has authority to correct
  errors of law and find facts in accordance with our own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415
  S.E.2d 812, 814 (1992).Â  However, â€œ[q]uestions concerning alimony rest with the
  sound discretion of the [family] court, whose conclusions will not be disturbed
  absent a showing of abuse of discretion.â€Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C.
  481, 485, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The family
  court abuses its discretion when factual findings are without evidentiary
  support or a ruling is based upon an error of law. Â Smith v. Doe, 366
  S.C. 469, 474, 623 S.E.2d 370, 372 (2005).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Wifeâ€™s Appeal
A.Â 
  Modification of Alimony 
Wife argues Husband
  has not proved a substantial change in circumstances has occurred such that a
  reduction in alimony is warranted.Â  We disagree.Â  
The
  party seeking the change in alimony has the burden to prove an unforeseen
  change in circumstances warrants a modification.Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324
  S.C. 481, 486, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œSeveral considerations
  relevant to the initial determination of alimony may be applied in the
  modification context as well, including the partiesâ€™ standard of living during
  the marriage, each partyâ€™s earning capacity, and the supporting spouseâ€™s
  ability to continue to support the other spouse.â€Â  Penny v. Green, 357
  S.C. 583, 589, 594 S.E.2d 171, 174 (Ct. App. 2004).
The
  South Carolina Supreme Court has emphasized it, â€œwill closely scrutinize the
  facts of any case wherein a husband and father voluntarily changes employment
  so as to lessen his earning capacity . . . .â€ Â Camp v. Camp, 269 S.C.
  173, 174, 236 S.E.2d 814, 815 (1977).Â  The Camp court held, â€œWhere the
  husband has voluntarily relinquished a well-paying practice and has taken a
  position at a modest salary, the court may base the amount of alimony upon his
  capacity to earn money, or upon his prospective earnings.â€Â  269 S.C. at 175,
  236 S.E.2d at 815.Â  Recently, the South Carolina Supreme Court held the motive
  behind a reduction in income may be a factor when courts consider earning
  capacity.Â  Arnal v. Arnal, 371 S.C. 10, 13, 636 S.E.2d 864, 866 (2006).Â 
  The court held the party â€œseeking to impute income to the other [party] need
  not establish a bad faith motivation to lower a support obligation in order to
  prove voluntary underemployment. The presence of bad faith is a factor in
  determining whether a [party] is voluntarily underemployed, but the lack of
  such bad faith does not preclude a finding of voluntary underemployment.â€[2] Â Id.Â  
In
  the present case, the family court found Husband proved a substantial change in
  circumstances warranting a reduction in alimony from $1,673 to $400 per month.Â 
  Husbandâ€™s substantial change in circumstances occurred after he terminated his
  employment with Michelin at the age of fifty-eight.Â  In September of 2001,
  Michelin sought to reduce its workforce and expenses.Â  Specifically, Michelin
  sought to reduce $275 million from their budget over a three-year span.Â 
  Husband testified his best option was to take an early retirement package
  Michelin offered and retire in 2002.Â  Husband made this decision based on his
  knowledge of events taking place at Michelin in addition to events happening in
  his own department.Â  Husband was making $54,000 per year at the time of the
  divorce.Â  However, the family court attributed this salary to Husbandâ€™s length
  of service at Michelin, rather than his earning capacity in the job market.Â 
  The family court stated Husband was â€œunder qualified to earn what he was
  earning, but for his years of service.â€Â  
In
  addition to his severance package of eleven months pay, Husband received
  retirement benefits and sought to increase profits of the CafÃ©, his existing
  business.Â  Husband also wished to expand this business by opening a deli.Â 
  After retiring from Michelin, unforeseen events caused Husbandâ€™s income to
  diminish.Â  First, the CafÃ© was forced to relocate because Husband lost his
  lease.Â  Under the CafÃ©â€™s new lease, monthly rent increased from $200 to
  $1,251.Â  In addition, Husbandâ€™s restaurant expansion, the Arvidia Deli, failed
  a year after opening.Â  We note Husband was legitimately concerned that he may
  have been fired if he had rejected Michelinâ€™s severance package.Â  Furthermore,
  Husbandâ€™s loss of the CafÃ©â€™s lease and his unsuccessful business venture with
  the Deli were all unforeseen and unanticipated changes in market conditions.Â  
Based
  on these unforeseen changed circumstances, we find the family court did not
  abuse its discretion in reducing Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation based on the
  above evidence and its finding that Husband made an â€œexcellent effortâ€ to
  supplement his income.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the family courtâ€™s decision to
  reduce alimony.Â  
B.Â 
  Amount of Alimony Reduction
Alternatively, Wife
  argues the family court erred in determining the amount of Husbandâ€™s reduced
  alimony obligation.Â  We disagree.
The family court
  initially ordered Husband to pay $1,673 per month in alimony to Wife after
  finding Husband earned $4,516 in gross monthly income from his job with
  Michelin, with a net monthly income of $2,915 after deductions.Â  Additionally
  in the divorce decree, the family court found Husband earned a profit of
  $29,884.55 from the CafÃ© during the first ten months of 2000.Â  At that time,
  the family court considered Husbandâ€™s two potential sources of income in its
  determination of alimony payments. Â 
In
  considering Husbandâ€™s request to decrease his alimony obligation, the family
  court recognized he is no longer receiving $4,516.00 in gross monthly income from
  his job with Michelin.Â  Additionally, the family court recognized â€œthat a
  business [Husband] established, known as Arvidiaâ€™s [D]eli, has now failed and
  he no longer has sufficient funds with which to pay his alimony obligation.â€Â 
  Consequently, Husband derives his sole source of income from the profit of the
  CafÃ©.Â  
The
  CafÃ©â€™s 10 month income statement showed a net income of $21,076.14 as of
  October 31, 2004.Â  However, we note the CafÃ©â€™s 11-month net income statement as
  of November 30, 2003, showed the business was operating at a net loss of
  $12,263.93 for 2003, and the October 2002 income statement showed the business
  producing a mere profit of $1,032 for 10 months in 2002.Â  In their testimony,
  Husband and his accountant, Gerald Saunders, corroborated these figures.Â 
  Moreover, net income from the CafÃ© pays off business loans and lines of credit
  and is used to acquire business assets; the net income does not all go directly
  to Husband as a salary.Â  Rather, Husband may take â€œdistributionsâ€ for personal
  expenses.Â  Husband testified he had drawn only $3,578.19 from the CafÃ© during
  the first six months of 2004.Â  Based on this distribution, Husband estimated
  $596 was his monthly salary from the CafÃ©.Â  Saunders later testified Husbandâ€™s
  annual distributions were $9,150 in 2002; $1,000 in 2003; and $6,785 in 2004.Â 
  Though Husbandâ€™s tax returns are not included as part of the trial record,
  Saunders also testified $16,090.92 was Husbandâ€™s taxable income in 2004.Â  The
  cash flow statement for the CafÃ© showed $16,090.92 as â€œincome per tax returnâ€
  in 2004, but these figures were negative for 2002 and 2003.Â  
Due
  to the nature of Husbandâ€™s business, it is difficult to determine his exact
  annual salary.Â  Instead, Husband withdraws his income from the CafÃ© based on
  available income after meeting debt obligations and making necessary business
  purchases.Â  Moreover, the family court found â€œnothing improper in [Husbandâ€™s]
  record keeping or expenditures,â€ nor did the family court believe Husband was
  hiding personal expenditures behind the CafÃ© or that he was â€œliving out ofâ€
  it.Â  We additionally note Husband has drawn against his retirement account for
  living expenses and to make loan payments.Â  
While
  we note the family court drastically decreased Wifeâ€™s alimony, after examining
  the record, we find the amount she receives is in line with Husbandâ€™s decreased
  earning capacity.Â  Additionally, we note Husbandâ€™s decreased income is partly
  attributable to unforeseen changes in market conditions.Â  Therefore, if a
  situation arises where Husbandâ€™s earnings increase, Wife has the ability to
  petition the family court for an increase in her monthly alimony based on
  changed circumstances.Â  However, in the meantime, we find the family court did
  not abuse its discretion in reducing the amount of alimony Husband owes and
  affirm the family courtâ€™s revised calculation of alimony.Â  
II.Â  Husbandâ€™s Appeal
Husband
  argues the federal bankruptcy law stays enforcement of the family courtâ€™s
  orders regarding the payment of Wifeâ€™s division of the marital property
  relating to 1) the CafÃ©; 2) Dodge automobile; 3) Wifeâ€™s award for past due
  COBRA payments; 4) past due attorneyâ€™s fees; and 5) attorneyâ€™s fees for the
  present action.Â  We agree.Â  
The filing of
  a petition for bankruptcy operates as an automatic stay of most state court
  proceedings.[3] Â 11 U.S.C.A. Â§ 362(a) (West 2004 & Supp. 2008).Â 
  â€œOnce a bankruptcy petition is filed, the bankruptcy court takes custody of all
  property in the debtorâ€™s possession.â€Â  Bragg v. Bragg, 347 S.C. 16, 24,
  553 S.E.2d 251, 255 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Upon such a filing, the debtorâ€™s property
  is under the jurisdiction of the bankruptcy court, and â€œno other Court, and no
  person acting under any process from any other Court, can, without the
  permission of the Bankrupt[cy] Court, interfere with it.â€ Bragg, 347
  S.C. at 24, 553 S.E.2d at 255 (internal citations omitted).Â  Due to the
  bankruptcy courtâ€™s exclusive jurisdiction over Husbandâ€™s debts, no action can
  be maintained in a state court to enjoin assets within the bankruptcy courtâ€™s
  jurisdiction, nor can a state court issue an order that would interfere with
  the jurisdiction of the bankruptcy court. Â Id. at 24, 553 S.E.2d at
  255-56. 
On
  September 23, 2005, Husband filed a petition for bankruptcy in the United
  States Bankruptcy Court for the District of South Carolina.Â  Thereafter, on
  March 14, 2006, the bankruptcy court issued its order confirming the Chapter 13
  Plan and resolving motions.Â  In the Chapter 13 Plan, Wife was listed as a
  priority creditor. Â The state courts no longer have jurisdiction over the debts
  owed Wife.Â  Accordingly, Husbandâ€™s appeal is held in abeyance.Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, we
  affirm the family courtâ€™s decision to reduce Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation due
  to a substantial and material change in his circumstances and hold the
  remaining issues in abeyance.Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART
  AND HELD IN ABEYANCE IN PART.
HUFF, KITTREDGE,
  and WILLIAMS, JJ. concur.Â  


[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Although the facts in Arnal involved reduction
  of child support payments, because voluntary underemployment occurs in the
  alimony arena as well, we find the situation analogous to alimony.Â  
[3]Â An action for the establishment or modification of
  an order for domestic support obligations is not subject to the bankruptcy
  automatic stay.Â  11 U.S.C.A. Â§ 362(b)(2)(A)(ii) (West Supp. 2008).

title: Jackson v. Rooms To Go Furniture
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.

	
		
			
				THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
				In The Court of Appeals
				Kim Jackson, Respondent,
				v.
				Rooms To Go
      Furniture, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
G. Edward Welmaker, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.  2008-UP-434
Submitted June 1, 2008 â€“ Filed August 4,
  2008
AFFIRMED 


	
		
			
				Kevin M. Elwell, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				Kim Jackson, of Simpsonville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Â Â Rooms
  To Go Furniture (Rooms To Go) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the
  magistrateâ€™s order, which awarded Kim Jackson (Jackson) damages.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Jackson purchased a living room set from Rooms To Go and had it delivered to her newly-built
  condominium, where her two children lived while they were in college.[2]Â  Jackson was not at the home when the
  furniture was delivered; however, her twenty-year-old son was present.Â  The son
  signed off on the delivery, indicating there was no damage.Â  The daughter testified
  she came home after the furniture was delivered and discovered the delivery men
  had damaged part of a wall and snagged the carpet.Â  The daughter then called Jackson to tell her about the damage.Â  Jackson called Rooms To Go and spoke with a claims
  manager, Janine Murphy.[3]Â 
  Jackson requested Rooms To Go repair the damage to her home.Â  In the meantime,
  Jackson hired her own painter to repaint the walls in her living room.Â  At
  trial, she testified she thought it cost $600 to repaint the living room.Â  She
  also testified she thought it would cost about $1,800 to $2,000 to replace the
  carpet.
Jackson and Murphy were unable to resolve the issue after numerous
  exchanges, and thus, Jackson filed an action in magistrate court on May 3, 2006.Â 
  After a non-jury trial in which Jackson represented herself, the magistrate ruled
  in Jacksonâ€™s favor, awarding her $2,500 in damages and $80 in costs.Â  Rooms To
  Go appealed to the circuit court on December 20, 2006.Â  On March 29, 2007,
  after a hearing that Jackson did not attend, the court affirmed the
  magistrateâ€™s order without any specific findings.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The standard of review to be applied by a circuit court
  in an appeal of a magistrateâ€™s judgment is prescribed by section 18-7-170 of
  the South Carolina Code:

	Upon
  hearing the appeal the appellate court shall give judgment according to the
  justice of the case, without regard to technical errors and defects which do
  not affect the merits. In giving judgment the court may affirm or reverse the
  judgment of the court below, in whole or in part, as to any or all the parties
  and for errors of law or fact.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-170 (1985); see also Hadfield v. Gilchrist, 343 S.C. 88, 92-93, 538 S.E.2d
  268, 270 (Ct. App. 2000); Burns v. Wannamaker, 281 S.C. 352, 357, 315
  S.E.2d 179, 182 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  
While
  the circuit court maintains a broad scope of review, our standard is more limited:

	[T]he
  Court of Appeals will presume that an affirmance by a Circuit Court of a
  magistrateâ€™s judgment was made upon the merits where the testimony is
  sufficient to sustain the judgment of the magistrate and there are no facts
  that show the affirmance was influenced by an error of law.

Burns, 281 S.C. at 357, 315 S.E.2d at 182; see also Price
  v. Charleston & W.C. Ry. Co., 93 S.C. 576, 578, 77 S.E. 703, 703
  (1913); Stanford v. Cudd, 93 S.C. 367, 370, 76 S.E. 986, 987 (1913).Â  â€œUnless
  we find an error of law, we will affirm the judgeâ€™s holding if there are any
  facts supporting his decision.â€Â  Hadfield, 343 S.C. at 94, 538 S.E.2d at
  271.
LAW / ANALYSIS
I.  Hearsay
Rooms
  To Go argues the circuit court erred by failing to reverse the magistrateâ€™s
  judgment because the magistrate allowed Jackson to refer to written estimates
  of her damages, which Rooms To Go contends was inadmissible hearsay.Â  We
  disagree.[4]Â  
The
  court did not allow Jackson to enter the estimates into evidence; however, it
  did allow her to state how much she thought it would cost to repaint the walls
  and replace the carpet.Â  â€œIt is the well-settled law of this state that an
  owner may testify as to the value of damaged real and personal property.â€Â  Waites
    v. S.C. Windstorm & Hail Underwriting Assocs., 279 S.C. 362, 366, 307
  S.E.2d 223, 225 (1983); see also Nelson v. Coleman Co., 249 S.C.
  652, 659-60, 155 S.E.2d 917, 921 (1967); Howell v. State Hwy. Depâ€™t, 167
  S.C. 217, 225, 166 S.E.2d 129, 132 (1932). 
Therefore,
  we find the circuit court did not err in allowing Jackson to testify to the
  value of her damaged property.Â Â  
II.  Incorrect Party
Rooms
  To Go argues the magistrate erred by ruling against it because Rooms To Go did
  not have a contract with Jackson.Â  Specifically, Rooms To Go argues it contracts
  with Southeast to deliver its furniture, thus the action should have been
  brought against Southeast instead of Rooms To Go because Southeast delivered Jacksonâ€™s furniture.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe
  necessary elements of a contract are an offer, acceptance, and valuable
  consideration.â€Â  Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of S.C., 354 S.C. 397, 406,
  581 S.E.2d 161, 166 (2003).Â  At trial, Jackson presented evidence she had a
  contract with Rooms To Go, not Southeast.Â  Jackson testified she paid Rooms To
  Go to deliver the furniture because Rooms To Go would not allow her to pick up
  the furniture herself.Â  Jackson was not aware a third party would be delivering
  her furniture.Â  Rooms To Go did not present any evidence otherwise.Â  Also,
  Murphy, the claims manager for Southeast, and the deliveryman testified
  Southeast only makes deliveries for Rooms To Go.
Thus,
  we find the magistrate did not err by ruling against Rooms To Go because Jackson contracted with Rooms To Go to deliver her furniture, not Southeast. 
CONCLUSION
Therefore,
  the order of the circuit court is Â 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Jackson testified she paid Rooms To Go to deliver the
  furniture because Rooms To Go would not allow her to pick up the furniture
  herself.Â  Jackson was not aware a third party would be delivering her
  furniture.Â  
[3]Â  Jackson testified she called the Rooms To Go â€œ1-800â€
  number to report the damage to her house; however, she spoke with Murphy, who
  later testified she worked for Southeast Independent Delivery Services, Inc.
  (Southeast) as a claims manager.
[4] Â Jackson did
  not file a respondentâ€™s brief.Â  The South Carolina Appellate Court Rules
  provide that â€œ[u]pon the failure of respondent to timely file a brief, the
  appellate court may take such action as it deems proper.â€Â  Rule 208(a)(4),
  SCACR.
